    <dl>
           <dt>&#x015b;a 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a</em> the first of the three sibilants (it belongs to the palatal class, but in sound as well as euphonic treatment often corresponds to <em>&#x1e63;</em>, though in some words pronounced more like <em>s</em>). -1</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. (for 2. p. 1045) the letter or sound <em>&#x015b;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-bheda</em> m. = next</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;abheda </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;bheda</em> m. N. of a treatise on the proper spelling of words beginning with <em>&#x015b;</em>, <em>&#x1e63;</em>, or s</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;avarga </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;varga</em> m. the sibilating class of letters, i.e. the three sibilants and the letter <em>h</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;a 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a</em> (ifc.) = <em>&#x015b;aya</em> ( <em>giri-</em>, <em>v&#x0101;ri-</em>, <em>v&#x1e5b;k&#x1e63;a-&#x015b;a</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;a 3</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a</em> m. = <em>&#x015b;astra</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;iva</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. 2. <em>&#x015b;am</em></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;a&#x1e43;sya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>), to recite, repeat (esp. applied to the recitation of texts in the invocations addressed by the Hot&#x1e5b;i to the Adhvaryu, when <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;s</em> is written <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e43;s</em> and the formulas <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e43;s&#x0101;mas</em>, <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e43;s&#x0101;vas</em>, <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e43;s&#x0101;va</em> are used </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. <em>&#x0101;-h&#x0101;va</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1044-1"></a>[Page 1044, Column 1]</font>

           <dd>&#x2022; to praise, extol <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to praise, commend, approve <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to vow, make a vow (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 85, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to wish anything (acc.) to (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> 124, 3 to relate, say, tell, report, declare, announce to (gen. or dat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; who or where anybody is', acc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also with two acc, 'to declare anybody or anything to be-') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to foretell, predict, prognosticate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to calumniate, revile <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to hurt, injure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be unhappy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Pass. <em>&#x015b;asy&#x00e1;te</em>, to be recited or uttered or praised or approved <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c.: Caus. <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;sayati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;a&#x015b;a&#x1e43;sat</em>), to cause to repeat or recite <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to predict, foretell <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>: Desid. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;a&#x1e43;si&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x015b;asyate</em>, <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x015b;a&#x1e43;sti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> [Cf. Lat. <em>carmen</em> for <em>casmen</em> ; <em>casme1na</em> <em>came1na</em> ; <em>censeo</em>.]</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;astr&#x00e1;</em> n. (for 2. under &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;as</em>) invocation, praise (applied to any hymn recited either audibly or inaudibly, as opp. to <em>stoma</em>, which is sung, but esp. the verses recited by the Hot&#x1e5b;i and his assistant as an accompaniment to the Grahas at the Soma libation) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; aor <em>&#x00e1;&#x015b;akat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. [Ved. also Pot. <em>&#x015b;akeyam</em> and <em>&#x015b;aky&#x0101;m</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. <em>&#x015b;agdhi</em>, <em>&#x015b;aktam</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;akt&#x0101;</em>, or <em>&#x015b;akit&#x0101;</em> Gr. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1044-2"></a>[Page 1044, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ak&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;aki&#x1e63;yate</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>-&#x015b;aktave</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;aktum</em> or <em>&#x015b;akitum</em> Gr.), to be strong or powerful, be able to or capable of or competent for (with acc., dat. or loc., rarely acc. of a verbal noun, or with an inf. in <em>am</em> or <em>tum</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with pr. p </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; e.g. with <em>graha&#x1e47;&#x0101;ya</em> or <em>graha&#x1e47;e</em>, 'to be able to seize' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vadha-nir&#x1e47;ekam</em> <em>a-&#x015b;aknuvan</em>, 'unable to atone for slaughter' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ak&#x00e9;ma v&#x0101;j&#x00ed;no y&#x00e1;mam</em>, 'may we be able to guide horses' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vii7k&#x1e63;itum</em> <em>na</em> <em>&#x015b;aknoti</em>, 'he is not able to see' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>p&#x016b;rayan na &#x015b;aknoti</em>, 'he is not able to fill') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (in these meanings ep. also <em>&#x015b;akyati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, with inf in <em>tu&#x1e43;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> Dh&#x0101;tup. xxvi, 78) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be strong or exert one's self for another (dat.), aid, help, assist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 67, 5 ; 68, 8 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to help to (dat. of thing) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> ii, 2, 12 ; iv, 21, 10 &amp;c.: Pass. <em>&#x015b;akyate</em> (ep. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em>), to be overcome or subdued, succumb <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to yield, give way <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be compelled or caused by any one (instr.) to (inf.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be able or capable or possible or practicable (with an inf. in pass. sense, e.g. <em>tat kartu&#x1e43; &#x015b;akyate</em>, 'that can be done' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes with pass. p., e.g. <em>na &#x015b;akyate v&#x0101;ryam&#x0101;&#x1e47;a&#x1e25;</em>, 'he cannot be restrained' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or used impers., with or with out instr., e.g. <em>yadi</em> [<em>tvay&#x0101;</em>] <em>&#x015b;akyate</em>, 'if it can be done by thee', if it is possible') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Caus. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;kayati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x012b;&#x015b;akat</em>), Gr.: Desid., &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;</em>. [Cf., accord. to some, Gk. ?, ?, ?, Germ. <em>&#x1e25;ag</em> <em>&#x1e25;ecke</em> [1044, 2] <em>hegen</em> ; <em>behagen</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;aka 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;aka</em> <em>su-&#x015b;&#x00e1;ka</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;akita </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;akita</em> mfn. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-2, 17) able, capable (mostly used with <em>na</em>, and giving a pass. sense to the inf., e.g. <em>na &#x015b;akita&#x1e43;</em> <em>chettum</em>, it could not be cut </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also impers., e.g. <em>na &#x015b;akita&#x1e43; tena</em>, he was not able) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;akta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;akta</em> mfn. able, competent for, equal to, capable of (instr., gen., dat., loc., acc. of person with <em>prati</em> inf., or comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;akita</em>, able to be (with inf. in a pass. sense) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-2, 17 m. N. of a son of Manasyu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;akti </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;kti</em> or f. power, ability, strength, might, effort, energy, capability (<em>&#x015b;akty&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x0101;tma-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em> or <em>sva-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, 'according to ability'</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;akti </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;akt&#x00ed;</em> f. power, ability, strength, might, effort, energy, capability (<em>&#x015b;akty&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x0101;tma-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em> or <em>sva-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, 'according to ability' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>para&#x1e43; &#x015b;akty&#x0101;</em>, with all one's might' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vitta-&#x015b;akty&#x0101;</em>, 'according to the capability of one's property' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;aktim a-h&#x0101;payitv&#x0101;</em>, 'not relaxing one's efforts, exerting all one's strength'), faculty, skill, capacity for, power over (gen., loc., dat., or inf.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; effectiveness or efficacy (of a remedy) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gS">&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; regal power (consisting of three parts, <em>prabhutva</em>, personal pre-eminence </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>mantra</em>, good counsel, and <em>uts&#x0101;ha</em>, energy) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;m">K&#x0101;m.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> iii, 13) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the energy or active power of a deity personified as his wife and worshipped by the &#x015a;&#x0101;kta (q.v.) sect of Hind&#x016b;s under various names (sometimes only three, sometimes eight &#x015a;akti goddesses are enumerated, as follow, Indr&#x0101;&#x1e47;i, Vaish&#x1e47;avii, &#x015a;&#x0101;nt&#x0101;, Brahm&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x012b;, Kaum&#x0101;ri, N&#x0101;rasi&#x1e43;h&#x012b;, V&#x0101;r&#x0101;h&#x012b;, and M&#x0101;he&#x015b;var&#x012b;, but some substitute C&#x0101;mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101; and C&#x0101;&#x1e47;dik&#x0101; for the third and sixth of these: according to another reckoning there are nine, viz. Vaish&#x1e47;avii, Brahm&#x0101;&#x1e47;i, Raudri, M&#x0101;he&#x015b;var&#x012b;, N&#x0101;rasi&#x1e43;h&#x012b;, V&#x0101;r&#x0101;h&#x012b;, Indra&#x1e47;&#x012b;, K&#x0101;rttik&#x012b;, and Pradh&#x0101;n&#x0101;: others reckon fifty different forms of the &#x015a;akti of Vish&#x1e47;u besides Lakshm&#x012b;, some of these are K&#x012b;rtti, K&#x0101;nti, Tush&#x1e6d;i, Push&#x1e6d;&#x0101;, Dh&#x1e5b;iti. &#x015a;&#x0101;nti, Kriy&#x0101;, Day&#x0101;, Medh&#x0101; &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and fifty forms of the &#x015a;akti of &#x015a;iva or Rudra besides Durg&#x0101;' or Gaur&#x012b;, some of whom are Gu&#x1e47;&#x00f4;dar&#x012b;, Viraj&#x0101;, S&#x0101;lmali, Lol&#x00e2;kshi, Vartul&#x00e2;ksh&#x012b;, D&#x012b;rgha-gho&#x1e47;&#x0101;, Sudirgha-mukh&#x012b;, Go-mukh&#x012b;, Dirgha-jihv&#x0101;, Ku&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x00f4;dar&#x012b;, Ardha-ke&#x015b;&#x012b;, Vik&#x1e5b;ita-mukh&#x012b;, Jv&#x0101;l&#x0101;-mukhi, Ulk&#x0101;mukhi &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Sarasvati is also named as a &#x015a;akti, both of Vish&#x1e47;u and Rudra: according to the V&#x0101;yu-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a the female nature of Rudra became twofold, one half <em>asita</em> or white, and the other <em>sita</em> or black, each of these again becoming manifold, those of the white or mild nature included Lakshm&#x012b;, Sarasvati, Gaur&#x012b;, Um&#x0101; &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; those of the dark and fierce nature, Durg&#x0101;, K&#x0101;li &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 181 &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MWB">MWB.</a> 216) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the female organ (as worshipped by the &#x015a;&#x0101;kta sect either actually or symbolically) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 140 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the power or signification of a word (defined in the Ny&#x0101;ya as <em>padasya pad&#x00e2;rthe</em> <em>sambandha&#x1e25;</em> i.e. 'the relation of a word to the thing designated') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bh&#x0101;sh&#x0101;p">Bh&#x0101;sh&#x0101;p.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in Gram.) case-power, the idea conveyed by a case (= <em>k&#x0101;raka</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-3, 7 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the power or force or most effective word of a sacred text or magic formula <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;car">Pa&#x00f1;car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the creative power or imagination (of a poet) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d">K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; help, aid, assistance, gift, bestowal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a spear, lance, pike, dart <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. (also <em>&#x015b;akt&#x012b;</em> g. <em>bahv-&#x0101;di</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a sword <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (prob.) a flag-staff ( <em>ratha-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1044-3"></a>[Page 1044, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. configuration of stars and planets (when the latter are situated in the 7th, 8th, 9th, and 10th astrological house), VirB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a Muni or sage (the eldest of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha's hundred sons </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> he was father of Par&#x0101;&#x015b;ara, and was devoured by king Kalm&#x0101;sha-p&#x0101;da, when changed to a man-eating R&#x0101;kshasa, in consequence of a curse pronounced upon him by the sage </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is represented as having overcome Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;mitra at the sacrifice of king Saud&#x0101;sa </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is regarded as the author of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 32, 26 ; ix, 97, 19-21 ; 108, 3 ; 14-16 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x015a;akti is also identified with one of the Vyl&#x0101;sas, and with Avalokit&#x00ea;&#x015b;vara, and has elsewhere the patr. J&#x0101;tukarna and S&#x0101;&#x1e43;k&#x1e5b;iti) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pravar">Pravar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;aktikara </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kara</em> mfn. producing strength <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#C&#x0101;&#x1e47;">C&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;aktigraha </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; taking hold of the force or meaning (of a word or sentence &amp;c. ) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a spearman, lancer </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of K&#x0101;rttikeya and &#x015a;iva </dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;aktigr&#x0101;haka </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tan may&#x0101; &#x015b;akyam prat&#x015b;pattum</em>, that is able to be acquired by me' </dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;aka 3</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;aka</em> m. pl. N. of a partic. whiteskinned tribe or race of people (in the legends which relate the contests between Vasish&#x1e6d;ha and Vi&#x015b;vamitra the &#x015a;akas are fabled to have been produced by the Cow of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha, from her sweat, for the destruction of Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;mitra's army ; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> x, 44, they are mentioned together with the Pau&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;rakas, O&#x1e0d;ras, Dravi&#x1e0d;as, K&#x0101;mbojas, Javanas or Yavanas, P&#x0101;radas, Pahlavas, C&#x012b;nas, Kir&#x0101;tas, Daradas, and Kha&#x015b;as, described by Kull&#x016b;ka as degraded tribes of Kshatriyas called after the districts in which they reside: according to the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> iv, 3, king Sagara attempted to rid his kingdom of these tribes, but did not succeed in destroying them all: they are sometimes regarded as the followers of &#x015a;aka or &#x015a;&#x0101;li-v&#x0101;hana, and are probably to be identified with the Tartars or Indo-Scythians [Lat. <em>saca</em>] who overran India before the &#x0100;ryans, and were conquered by the great Vikram&#x00e2;ditya <em>q.v.</em> ; they really seem to have been dominant in the north-west of India in the last century before and the first two centuries after the beginning of our era) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>Pari&#x015b;. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a king of the &#x015a;akas, g. <em>kamboj&#x00e2;di</em> (on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-1, 175 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an era, epoch (cf. <em>-k&#x0101;la</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a year (of any era) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Inscr">Inscr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. fragrant substance <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gal">Gal.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;akakart&#x1e5b; </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; a king's brother-in-law through one of his inferior wives (esp. in the drama represented as a foolish, frivolous, proud, low, and cruel man, such as is Sa&#x1e43;sth&#x0101;naka in the M&#x1e5b;icchaka&#x1e6d;ik&#x0101;, he speaks the dialect of the &#x015a;ikas i.e. &#x015a;&#x0101;k&#x0101;r&#x012b;, which employs the sibilant &#x015b;, exclusively <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1046-1"></a>[Page 1046, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence &#x015a;ak&#x0101;ra, accord. to some, is for, '&#x015a;a-k&#x0101;ra', one who uses the letter &#x015a;a) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhar">Bhar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;aka&#x1e6d;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;aka&#x1e6d;a</em> n. (rarely m. of doubtful derivation) a cart, waggon, car, carriage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>pr&#x0101;j&#x0101;patyam</em>, or <em>rohi&#x1e47;y&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>, cf. <em>rohi&#x1e47;&#x012b;-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) the five stars forming the asterism Rohi&#x1e47;&#x012b; compared to a cart <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (only) n. a partic. configuration of stars and planets (when all the planets are in the Ist and 7th house) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. n. a form of military array resembling a wedge <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 187 </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;akun&#x00e1;</em> m. (said to be fr. &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;ak</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> iii, 49) a bird (esp. a large bird or one of good or bad omen) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. kind of bird (either = <em>gridhra</em>, a vulture, or = <em>cilla</em>, a common kite or Pondicherry eagle) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>vasi&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;hasya</em>) N. of a S&#x0101;man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;rshBr">&#x0100;rshBr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of an Asura <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. col. 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. any auspicious object or lucky omen, an omen or prognostic (in general </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; mfn. indicating good luck, auspicious <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (in astronomy) N. of the first fixed <em>kara&#x1e47;a</em> (q.v.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of the brother of queen Gandh&#x0101;r&#x012b; (and therefore the brother-in-law of Dh&#x1e5b;ita-r&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra and the M&#x0101;tula or maternal uncle of the Kuru princes </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as son of Subala, king of G&#x0101;ndh&#x0101;ra, he is called Saubala </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he often acted as counsellor of Duryodhana, and hence his name is sometimes applied to an old officious relative whose counsels ten to misfortune) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; of the great-grandfather of A&#x015b;oka <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;akuntal&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;akuntal&#x0101;</em> f. (said to be fr. <em>&#x015b;akunta</em>) N. of a daughter of the Apsaras Menak&#x0101; by Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;mitra (she was supposed to have been born and left in a forest, where she was protected by birds till found by the sage Ka&#x1e47;va, who took her to his hermitage and reared her as his daughter </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; she was there seen by king Dushyanta, when on a hunting expedition, and married by him, and became the mother of Bharata, sovereign of all India </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the story of Dushyanta's accidental meeting with &#x015a;akuntal&#x0101;, their marriage, separation, his repudiation of her through temporary loss of memory caused by a curse, his subsequent recognition of her by means of a ring which was lost but afterwards recovered, forms the subject of Kalid&#x0101;sa's celebrated drama called Abhij&#x00f1;&#x0101;na-&#x015b;akuntal&#x0101;, q.v.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;akuntal&#x0101;tmaja </dt>

           <dt>&#x015b;at </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;at</em> <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;tayati</em>, &#x221a;2. <em>&#x015b;ad</em>, p. 1051</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ata </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;at&#x00e1;</em> n. (rarely m </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. f. <em>&#x012b;</em>) a hundred (used with other numerals thus, <em>ek&#x00e2;dhika&#x1e43; &#x015b;atam</em>, or <em>eka-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a hundred + one, 101 <em>vi&#x1e43;&#x015b;aty-adhika&#x1e43; &#x015b;atam</em> or <em>vi&#x1e43;&#x015b;a&#x1e43; &#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a hundred + twenty, 120 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ate</em> or <em>dve &#x015b;ate</em> or <em>dvi-&#x015b;atam</em> or <em>&#x015b;ata-dvayam</em>, 200 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tr&#x012b;&#x1e47;i</em> <em>&#x015b;at&#x0101;ni</em> or <em>tri-&#x015b;at&#x0101;ni</em> or <em>&#x015b;ata-trayam</em>, 300 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x1e63;a&#x1e6d;-&#x015b;atam</em>, 600 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or the comp. becomes an ordinal, e.g. <em>dvi-&#x015b;ata</em>, the 200th </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dvika&#x1e43;</em>, <em>trika&#x1e43; &#x015b;atam</em> = 2, 3 per cent </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;at&#x0101;tpara</em>, 'beyonda hundred, exceeding 100' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the counted object is added either in the gen., or in the same case as <em>&#x015b;ata</em>, or ibc., e.g. <em>&#x015b;atam pitara&#x1e25;</em> or, <em>&#x015b;atam pit&#x1e5d;&#x1e47;&#x0101;m</em> or <em>pit&#x1e5b;-&#x015b;atam</em> a hundred ancestors' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes also ifc., comp. below </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely <em>&#x015b;atam</em> is used as an indecl. with an instr., e.g. <em>&#x015b;at&#x00e1;&#x1e43; r&#x00e1;thebhi&#x1e25;</em>, 'with a hundred chariots' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 48, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely occurs a masc. form in pl., e.g. <em>pa&#x00f1;ca-&#x015b;at&#x0101;</em>, <em>rath&#x0101;n</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 1057 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and <em>&#x015b;ata</em> n. rarely in comp. of the following kind, <em>catur-var&#x1e63;a-&#x015b;atam</em> or <em>&#x25cb;t&#x0101;ni</em>, '400 years') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any very large number (in comp. as <em>&#x015b;ata-pattra</em> &amp;c. below). [Cf. Gk. ? 'one' hundred ; [1048, 3] Lat. <em>centum</em> ; Lith. <em>s&#x015b;mtas</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Got. (twa) <em>hunda</em> ; Germ. <em>hund-ert</em> ; Eng. <em>hund-ed</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ata&#x1e43;hima </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; containing a hundred sacrificial rites (<em>ek&#x00f4;na-&#x015b;ata-kr&#x25cb;</em>, one who has made 99 sacrifices) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1049-1"></a>[Page 1049, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of Indra (a hundred A&#x015b;va-medhas elevating the sacrificer to the rank of Indra </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; proceeding in a hundred ways <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Si&#x1e43;h&#x00e2;s">Si&#x1e43;h&#x00e2;s.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a</em> n. the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a with a hundred paths or sections', N. of a well-known Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a attached to the V&#x0101;jasaneyi-samhit&#x0101; or White Yajur-veda, (like the Sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;, this Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a is ascribed to the &#x1e5a;ishi Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;avalkya </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is perhaps the most modern of the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as, and is preserved in two S&#x0101;kh&#x0101;s or schools, M&#x0101;dhyampdina and K&#x0101;&#x1e47;va </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the version belonging to the former is best known, and is divided into fourteen K&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;as or books which contain one hundred Adhy&#x0101;yas or lectures <em>or according to another arrangement into sixty-eight Praps&#x1e6d;hakas</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the whole work is regarded as the most systematic and interesting of all the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as, and though intended mainly for ritual and sacrificial purposes, is full of curious mythological details and legends </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>yajur-veda</em>, <em>vijasaneyisa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;</em>, <em>br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 25 &amp;c </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;cara</em> mfn. walking or moving slowly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. the planet Saturn or its regent (cf. <em>&#x015b;ani</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c. (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> also applied to other planets and even the sun) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Saturday <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vish&#x1e47;">Vish&#x1e47;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kavaca</em> m. n. <em>-p&#x016b;j&#x0101;</em> f. N. of wks </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-v&#x0101;ra</em> m. Saturday <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Subh">Subh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-vidh&#x0101;na</em> n. <em>-vrata</em> n. N. of wks </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-sa&#x1e43;vatsara</em> m. the year of Saturn (during which this planet completes his course through the 28 Nakshatras </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in modern astron. = 30 of our years) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ap 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ap</em> (in gram.) a technical term used for the Vikara&#x1e47;a a (inserted between the &#x221a;and terminations of the conjugational tenses in verbs of the Ist class </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>vi-kara&#x1e47;a</em>, p. 954)</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ap 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ap</em> ind. a prefix implying assent or acceptance (as in <em>&#x015b;ap-karoti</em>, he admits or accepts) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ap 3</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ap</em> cl. 1. 4. P. &#x0100;. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxiii, 31 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; xxvi, 59) <em>&#x015b;apati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> or <em>&#x015b;apyati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (the latter only in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x015b;a&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x0341;pa</em>, <em>&#x015b;ep&#x00e9;</em> aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x0101;ps&#x012b;t</em>, <em>a&#x015b;apta</em> Gr. [2. pl. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;pta</em> in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> prob. w&#x1e5b;. ] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;apt&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;apsyati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;api&#x1e63;ye</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x015b;aptum</em> or <em>&#x015b;apitum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;apitv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;aptv&#x0101;</em> Gr.), to curse (mostly P. with acc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> v, 30, 3, &#x0100;. with dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (P. &#x0100;.) to swear an oath, utter an execration (sometimes with <em>&#x015b;apatham</em> or <em>&#x25cb;th&#x0101;n</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also with <em>an&#x1e5b;tam</em>, to swear a false oath) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (P. &#x0100;.) to revile, scold, blame (acc., rarely dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. c. also P.) to curse one's self (followed by <em>yadi</em>, 'if', i. e. to promise with an oath, vow or swear, 'that one will not' &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or followed by dat. and rarely acc. of the person to whom and instr. of the object by which one swears </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or followed by <em>iti</em> e.g. <em>varu&#x1e47;&#x00ea;ti</em>, 'to swear by the name of Varu&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;) to adjure, supplicate, conjure any one (acc.) by (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a>: Caus. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;payati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x012b;&#x015b;apat</em>), to adjure, conjure, exorcise (demons) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause any one (acc.) to swear by (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii, 113 (cf. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;pita</em>): Desid. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;apsati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x015b;apyate</em>, <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x015b;apti</em>, or <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;&#x015b;pyate</em>, <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;&#x015b;apti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;abara </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;abara</em> mfn. - (also written <em>&#x015b;avara</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>&#x015b;abala</em> below) variegated, brindled <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating or belonging to a &#x015a;abara (prob. for <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;bara</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a wild mountaineer tribe in the Deccan (in later language applied to any savage or barbarian = <em>kir&#x0101;ta</em>, <em>pulinda</em>, <em>bhilla</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> 'the son of a &#x015a;&#x016b;dra and a Bhill&#x012b;') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of Lodhra or Lodh tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. comp.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>k&#x0101;&#x1e63;ivata</em>) N. of the author of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 169 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Anukr">Anukr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a poet <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a Buddhist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;abara-sv&#x0101;min</em> (in <em>&#x015b;abara-bh&#x0101;&#x1e63;ya</em>, q.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>hasta</em> and <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;stra-vi&#x015b;e&#x1e63;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of a Yogin&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a &#x015a;abara woman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. water <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (prob. w&#x1e5b;. for <em>&#x015b;ambara</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;abda </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;bda</em> m. (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dhy&#x0101;nabUp">Dhy&#x0101;nabUp.</a> also n. ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em> perhaps connected with &#x221a;3. <em>&#x015b;ap</em>, cf. also 2. <em>&#x015b;ap</em>) sound, noise, voice, tone, note (<em>&#x015b;abda&#x1e43;</em> &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to utter a sound, raise the voice, cry aloud </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sound is supposed to be sevenfold [cf. MBh. xii, 6858] or eight. fold [cf. Dharmas. 35] or tenfold [cf. MBh. xiv, 1418] <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1052-3"></a>[Page 1052, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the M&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101; it is taught to be eternal) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a word (<em>&#x015b;abdena</em>, by word, explicitly, expressly) cf. ib. cf. K&#x0101;&#x015b;. on cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 2-3, 19 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; speech, language cf. BhP </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (in gram.) a declinable word or a word-termination, affix cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. cf. Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a name, appellation, title cf. Mn. cf. MBh. &amp;c. (<em>tacchabd&#x0101;t</em>', because it is socalled' cf. K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a technical term cf. TPr&#x0101;t </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-garbha-vat</em> mfn. containing (virtually) sound and meaning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;matUp">R&#x0101;matUp.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;sambh&#x0101;ra</em> m. (with Buddhists) quietude as one of the equipments (one of the 4 Sambh&#x0101;ras, q.v.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 117</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;amana </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; chewing, swallowing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of cymbal or other musical instrument (= <em>t&#x0101;la-vi&#x015b;e&#x1e63;a</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>-k&#x1e63;epa</em>, <em>-nip&#x00e2;ta</em> &amp;c. below) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. (<em>dhuro&#x1e25; &#x015b;amye</em>) N. of two &#x015a;&#x0101;mans <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;rshBr">&#x0100;rshBr.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;amy&#x0101;k&#x1e63;epa </dt>

           <dt>&#x015b;am 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;m</em> ind. (g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em> and <em>svar-&#x0101;di</em>) auspiciously, fortunately, happily, well (frequently used in the Veda, rarely in later language ; often to be translated by a subst., esp. in the frequent phrase <em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;&#x1e43; y&#x00f3;&#x1e25;</em> or <em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;&#x1e43; ca y&#x00f3;&#x015b; ca</em>, 'happiness and welfare', sometimes joined with the verbs <em>bh&#x016b;</em>, as, <em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, <em>d&#x0101;vah</em>, <em>y&#x0101;</em>, sometimes occurring without any verb ; with dat. or gen. [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 2-3, 73 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>] ; in some cases corresponding to an adj., e.g. <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43; tad asmai</em>, that is pleasant to him) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Br&#x0101;hman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>tarkaka</em> and <em>dh&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. (also written <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x1e43;tanu</em>) N. of an ancient king with the patr. Kauravya (he was fourteenth descendant of Kuru, son of Prat&#x012b;pa and younger brother of Dev&#x0101;pi, and usurped the sovereignty whilst the latter became a hermit </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he married Ga&#x1e45;g&#x0101; and &#x015a;atya-vati </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; by the former he had a son named Bh&#x012b;shma, and by the latter Citr&#x00e2;&#x1e45;gada and Vicitravirya, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> IW. 375) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>cakra-vartin</em>) N. of an author (son of Uddhara&#x1e47;a, of the Tomara race) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tan&#x016b;ja</em> m. 'son of &#x015a;a&#x1e43;tanu', N. of Bh&#x012b;shma, &#x015a;is. xv, 20</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x00e2;v&#x0101;sa</em> m. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of camphor <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x0101;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;aka </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x00e2;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;aka</em> n. N. of wk. by Lakshm&#x012b;-n&#x0101;r&#x0101;yana</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em> m. N. of various teachers and authors, (esp.) of a celebrated teacher of the Ved&#x00e2;nta philosophy and reviver of Br&#x0101;hmanism (he is thought to have lived between A&#x1e0c;. 788 and 820, but according to tradition he flourished 200 B.c., and was a native of Kerala or Malabar </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; all accounts describe him as having led an erratic controversial life </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his leaming and sanctity were in such repute that he was held to have been an incarnation of &#x015a;iva, and to have worked various miracles </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is said to have died at the age of thirty-two, and to have had four principal disciples, called Padma-p&#x0101;da, Hast&#x00e2;malaka, Sure&#x015b;vara or Mandana, and Tro&#x1e6d;aka </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; another of his disciples, &#x0100;nanda-giri, wrote a history of his controversial exploits, called &#x015a;a&#x1e43;kara-vijaya, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; tradition makes him the founder of one of the principal &#x015a;aiva sects, the Da&#x015b;a-n&#x0101;mi-Da&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ins or 'Ten-named Mendicants' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 87 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is the reputed author of a large number of original works, such as the &#x0100;tma-bodha, &#x0100;nanda-lahari, J&#x00f1;&#x0101;na -bodhin&#x012b;, Ma&#x1e47;i-ratna-m&#x0101;l&#x0101;, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and commentaries on the Upanishads, and on the Brahma-m&#x012b;m&#x0101;&#x1e43;s&#x0101; or Ved&#x0101;nta-s&#x016b;tra, Bhagavadg&#x012b;t&#x0101;, and Mah&#x0101;-bh&#x0101;rata, &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 46 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 53 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-carita</em> n. <em>-vijaya-&#x1e0d;i&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ima</em> (cf. <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kara-digvijaya-&#x1e0d;&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;ry&#x00e2;vat&#x0101;ra-kath&#x0101;</em> f. <em>&#x25cb;ry&#x00f4;tpatti</em> f. N. of wks</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kar&#x012b;</em> f. the wife of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Rubia Munjista <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prosopis Spicigera or Mimosa Suma <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-g&#x012b;ta</em> n. <em>-g&#x012b;ti</em> f. N. of musical wks</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; sa&#x1e43;kar&#x012b;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>sa&#x1e43;kar&#x012b;ya</em> mfn. (fr. <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;kara</em>), g. <em>utkar&#x00e2;di</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. N. of wk</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;anta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;anta</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;anti </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; it is represented as stronger than the lion and the elephant </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>a&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a-pad</em> and <em>mah&#x0101;-skandhin</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a young elephant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a locust <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of an Upanishad (cf. <em>&#x015b;arabh&#x00f4;pani&#x1e63;ad</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of an Asura <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of two serpent-demons <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of various men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of brother of &#x015a;akuni <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a prince of the A&#x015b;makas <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcar">Hcar.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a monkey in R&#x0101;ma's army <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) N. of a people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (B. <em>&#x015b;abara</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a girl with withered limbs and therefore unfit for marriage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;S">G&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (prob.) a kind of wooden machine. [Cf., accord. to some, Gk., ?, ?.] [1057, 2]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; patr. fr. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;ka</em>, or <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;kin</em> g. <em>kurv-&#x0101;di</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x0341;kh&#x0101;</em> f. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x012b;</em>) a branch (lit. and fig.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a limb of the body, arm or leg <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a finger <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> ii, 5 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the surface of the body <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a door-post <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> (cf. <em>dv&#x0101;ra-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the wing of a building <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a division, subdivision <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the third part of an astrological Sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101; (also <em>&#x25cb;kh&#x0101;-skandha</em>, m.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a branch or school of the Veda (each school adhering to its own traditional text and interpretation </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Cara&#x1e47;a-vy&#x016b;ha, a work by &#x015a;aunaka treating of these various schools, five &#x015a;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;s are enumerated of the &#x1e5a;ig-veda, viz. those of the &#x015a;&#x0101;kalas, B&#x0101;shkalas, &#x0100;&#x015b;val&#x0101;yanas, &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x0101;yanas, and M&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;uk&#x0101;yanas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; forty-two or forty-four out of eighty-six of the Yajur-veda, fifteen of which belong to the V&#x0101;jasaneyins, including those of the K&#x0101;&#x1e47;vas and M&#x0101;dhya&#x1e43;dinas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; twelve out of a thousand said to have once existed of the S&#x0101;ma-veda and nine of the Atharva-veda </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of all these, however, the &#x1e5a;ig-veda is said to be now extant in one only, viz. the &#x015a;&#x0101;kala-&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;, the Yajur-veda in five and partially in six, the S&#x0101;ma-veda in one or perhaps two, and the Atharva-veda in one: although the words <em>cara&#x1e47;a</em> and <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;</em> are sometimes used synonymously, yet <em>cara&#x1e47;a</em> properly applies to the sect or collection of persons united in one school, and <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;</em> to the traditional text followed, as in the phrase <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;m adh&#x012b;te</em>, he recites a particular version of the Veda) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a branch of any science <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a year <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;r&#x012b;ka&#x1e47;&#x1e6d;h">&#x015a;r&#x012b;ka&#x1e47;&#x1e6d;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>pak&#x1e63;&#x00e2;ntara</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>antika</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;&#x0101;ci 1</dt>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x0101;nti </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x0341;nti</em> f. tranquillity, peace, quiet, peace or calmness of mind, absence of passion, averting of pain (<em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nti</em>! <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nti</em>! <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nti</em>! may the three kinds of pain be averted!), indifference to objects of pleasure or pain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ka&#x1e6d;hUp">Ka&#x1e6d;hUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; alleviation (of evil or pain), cessation, abatement, extinction (of fire &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a pause, breach, interruption <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any expiatory or propitiatory rite for averting evil or calamity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 346) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; peace, welfare, prosperity, good fortune, ease, comfort, happiness, bliss <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; destruction, end, eternal rest, death <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nti-kalpa</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Tranquillity &amp;c. personified (as a daughter of &#x015a;raddh&#x0101;, as the wife of Atharvan, as the daughter of Daksha and wife of Dharma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Prab">Prab.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a son of Indra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of Indra in the tenth Manv-antara <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;&#x0101;rada </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;rad&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em>, or <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x0341;rad&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>&#x015b;arad</em>) produced or growing in autumn, autumnal, mature <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (prob.) that which offers a shelter in autumn (against the overflowings of rivers </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; applied to <em>puras</em> or 'castles' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; others 'rich in years', 'old') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 131, 4 ; 174, 2 ; vi, 20, 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; new, recent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (perhaps <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> i, 47 in <em>salila&#x1e43; &#x015b;&#x0101;radam</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. also <em>rajju-&#x015b;&#x0101;rada</em> and <em>d&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;ac-ch&#x0101;rada</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; modest, shy, diffident cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a year cf. L.' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a cloud cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of various plants (a yellow kind of Phaseolus Mungo </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Mimusops Elengi &amp;c.) cf. L. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1066-2"></a>[Page 1066, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; autumnal sickness cf. W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; autumnal sunshine cf. ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a teacher of Yoga (v&#x1e37;. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;bara</em>) cf. Cat </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. below </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. (only cf. L.) the day of full moon in the month K&#x0101;rttika (or &#x0100;&#x015b;vina) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Jussiaea Repens </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Alstonia Scholaris </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. corn, grain, fruit (as ripening in autumn) cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the white lotus cf. L</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;&#x0101;radabh&#x016b;ruh </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; a lump or ball of meat </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; its thorns are supposed to be used for torture in one of the hells [cf. <em>k&#x016b;ta-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>], or it may stand for the N. of that hell) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;i&#x1e63;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;&#x0101;sya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.), to chastise, correct, censure, punish <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to restrain, control, rule, govern (also with <em>r&#x0101;jyam</em> or <em>ai&#x015b;varyam</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to administer the laws (with <em>dharmam</em>, 'to adm&#x1e6d;administer justice') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to direct, bid, order, command, enjoin, decree (with an inf. or a sentence followed by <em>iti</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to teach, instruct, inform (with two acc., or with acc. of pers. and dat. or loc. of thing) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to confess (a crime) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> xi, 82 </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x0101;sana </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x0341;sana</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. punishing, a punisher, chastiser ( <em>p&#x0101;ka-</em>, <em>pura-</em>, <em>rukmi-</em>, <em>smara-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1069-1"></a>[Page 1069, Column 1]</font> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) punishment, chastisement, correction (<em>&#x015b;&#x0101;sana&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, to inflict punishment) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Baudh">Baudh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; government, dominion, rule over (comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an order, command, edict, enactment, decree, direction (<em>&#x015b;&#x0101;sana&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em> [<em>k&#x0101;&#x1e45;k&#x1e63;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Baudh">Baudh.</a>] or <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;sane-&#x221a;v&#x1e5b;t</em> or <em>sth&#x0101;</em>, 'to obey orders' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;san&#x0101;t</em> with gen., 'by command of' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;san&#x0101;</em> f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> xiv, 36) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a royal edict, grant, charter (usually a grant of land or of partic. privileges, and often inscribed on stone or copper) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a writing, deed, written contract or agreement <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;st&#x1e5b;ka</em> mfn. coming from a teacher <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-2, 104 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 15 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x0101;stra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x0101;str&#x00e1;</em> n. an order, command, precept, rule <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; teaching, instruction, direction, advice, good counsel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any instrument of teaching, any manual or compendium of rules, any bock or treatise, (esp.) any religious or scientific treatise, any sacred book or composition of divine authority (applicable even to the Veda, and said to be of fourteen or even eighteen kinds [see under <em>vidy&#x0101;</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the word <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;stra</em> is often found ifc. after the word denoting the subject of the book, or is applied collectively to whole departments of knowledge, e.g. <em>ved&#x00e2;nta-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a work on the Ved&#x00e2;nta philosophy or the whole body of teaching on that subject </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dharma-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a law-book or whole body of written laws </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>k&#x0101;vya-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a poetical work or poetry in general </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ilpi-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, works on the mechanical arts </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>k&#x0101;ma-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, erotic compositions </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ala&#x1e43;k&#x0101;ra &#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, rhetoric, &amp;c.)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a body of teaching (in general), scripture, science <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely P.) to learn, acquire knowledge, study, practise, learn from (abl. or <em>sak&#x0101;&#x015b;&#x0101;t</em> with gen.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to practise one's self in (loc.)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-3, 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'to wish to be able to effect for others' (P.) wish to help, aid, befriend (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (P.) to wish to give, bestow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (P.) to wish to present with (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;.) to offer one's service to, enter the service of (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>: Pass. <em>&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;yate</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;i</em>), to be learnt or practised <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a>: Caus. <em>&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;ayati</em> (rarely <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;at</em>), to cause to learn, impart knowledge, inform, instruct, teach (with acc. of pers. or thing </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also with two acc., or with acc. of pers. and loc. of thing, or with acc. of pers. and inf., or with acc. of thing and gen. of pers.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;ikha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;in </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a king (renowned for his liberality and unselfishness, and said to have saved Agni transformed into a dove from Indra transformed into a hawk by offering an equal quantity of his own flesh weighed in a balance) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) a people descended from &#x015a;ibi <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of Indra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; instr. with &#x221a;<em>gam</em>, <em>abhi-&#x221a;gam</em>, <em>pra-&#x221a;grah</em>, &#x221a;<em>y&#x0101;</em>, <em>pra-&#x1e47;am</em> [&#x221a;<em>nam</em>], <em>ni-&#x221a;pat</em>, <em>pra-&#x1e47;i-&#x221a;pat</em>, 'to touch with the head, bow or fall down before' </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;ilpi</em> in comp. for <em>&#x015b;ilpin</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpikarman </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;karman</em> n. the work of an artisan <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Divy&#x00e2;v">Divy&#x00e2;v.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpijana </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;jana</em> (cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S.), m. an artisan, craftsman</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpi&#x015b;&#x0101;la </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;&#x0101;la</em> n. or a workshop, manufactory <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpi&#x015b;&#x0101;l&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x1e0d;l&#x0101;</em> f. a workshop, manufactory <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpi&#x015b;&#x0101;stra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;&#x0101;stra</em> n. = <em>&#x015b;ilpa-&#x015b;&#x0101;stra</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ilpis&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;s&#x0101;ra</em> m. olibanum <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gal">Gal.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;ilpika </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ilpika</em> mfn. skilled in art (applied to &#x015a;iva) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#N&#x012b;lak">N&#x012b;lak.</a> = little versed in art) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. any handicraft or mechanical art <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of drama (= <em>&#x015b;ilpaka</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. <em>&#x015b;ilpaka</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;ilpin </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ilpin</em> mfn. belonging to or skilled in art </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. an artificer, artisan, craftsman, artist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gaut">Gaut.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (ifc.) fashioner of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>in&#x012b;</em>), f. a female artisan or artist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of herb or grass (commonly called Lah&#x0101;nasip&#x012b;, used medicinally: otherwise described as a perfume = <em>kola-dala</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ilha&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ilha&#x1e47;a</em> m. (also written <em>&#x015b;ilhana</em> and <em>&#x015b;ihla&#x1e47;a</em>) N. of a poet from Ka&#x015b;m&#x012b;ra (author of the &#x015a;&#x0101;nti-&#x015b;ataka)</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;iva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;iv&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>)n. (according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> i, 153, fr. &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;</em>, 'in whom all things lie' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; perhaps connected with &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;vi</em>, cf. <em>&#x015b;avas</em>, <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;vi</em>) auspicious, propitious, gracious, favourable, benign, kind, benevolent, friendly, dear (<em>&#x00e1;m</em> ind. kindly, tenderly) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; happy, fortunate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. happiness, welfare (cf. n.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> v, 56, 36 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; liberation, final emancipation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'The Auspicious one', N. of the disintegrating or destroying and reproducing deity (who constitutes the third god of the Hind&#x016b; Trim&#x016b;rti or Triad, the other two being Brahm&#x0101; 'the creator' and Vish&#x1e47;u 'the preserver' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Veda the only N. of the destroying deity wss Rudra 'the terrible god', but in later times it became usual to give that god the euphemistic N. &#x015a;iva 'the auspicious' [just as the Furies were called ? 'the gracious ones'], and to assign him the office of creation and reproduction as well as dissolution </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in fact the preferential worship of &#x015a;iva as developed in the Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as and Epic poems led to his being identified with the Supreme Being by his exclusive worshippers <em>called "&#x1e63;aivas</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in his character of destroyer he is sometimes called K&#x0101;la 'black', and is then also identified with Time', although his active destroying function is then oftener assigned to his wife under her name K&#x0101;l&#x012b;, whose formidable character makes her a general object of propitiation by sacrifices </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as presiding over reproduction consequent on destruction &#x015a;iva's symbol is the Li&#x1e45;ga <em>q.v.</em> or Phallus, under which form he is worshipped all over India at the present day </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; again one of his representations is as Ardha-n&#x0101;r&#x012b;, 'half-female', the other half being male to symbolize the unity of the generative principle [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 85] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he has three eyes, one of which is in his forehead, and which are thought to denote his view of the three divisions of time, past, present, and future, while a moon's crescent, above the central eye, marks the measure of time by months, a serpent round his neck the measure by years, and a second necklace of skulls with other serpents about his person, the perpetual revolution of ages, and the successive extinction and generation of the races of mankind: his hair is thickly matted together, and gathered above his forehead into a coil </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; on the top of it he bears the Ganges, the rush of which in its descent from heaven he intercepted by his head that the earth might not be crushed by the weight of the falling stream </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his throat is dark-blue from the stain of the deadly poison which would have destroyed the world had it not been swallowed by him on its production at the churning of the ocean by the gods for the nectar of immortality </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he holds a <em>tri-&#x015b;&#x016b;la</em>, or three-pronged trident <em>also called Pin&#x0101;ka</em> in his hand to denote, as some think, his combination of the three attributes of Creator, Destroyer, and Regenerator </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he also carries a kind of drum, shaped like an hour-glass, called &#x1e0c;amaru: his attendants or servants are called Pramatha <em>qq.vv.</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are regarded as demons or supernatural beings of different kinds, and form various hosts or troops called Ga&#x1e47;as </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his wife Durg&#x0101; [otherwise called K&#x0101;l&#x012b;, P&#x0101;rvat&#x012b;, Um&#x0101;, Gaur&#x012b;, Bhav&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x012b; &amp;c.] is the chief object of worship with the &#x015a;&#x0101;ktas and T&#x0101;ntrikas, and in this connection he is fond of dancing [see <em>t&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ava</em>] and wine-drinking <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1074-2"></a>[Page 1074, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is also worshipped as a great ascetic and is said to have scorched the god of love (K&#x0101;ma-deva) to ashes by a glance from his central eye, that deity having attempted to inflame him with passion for P&#x0101;rvat&#x012b; whilst he was engaged in severe penance </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the exercise of his function of Universal Destroyer he is fabled to have burnt up the Universe and all the gods, including Brahm&#x0101; and Vish&#x1e47;u, by a similar scorching glance, and to have rubbed the resulting ashes upon his body, whence the use of ashes in his worship, while the use of the Rudr&#x00e2;ksha berries originated, it is said, from the legend that &#x015a;iva, on his way to destroy the three cities, called Tri-pura, let fall some tears of rage which became converted into these beads: his residence or heaven is Kail&#x0101;sa, one of the loftiest northern peaks of the Him&#x00e2;laya </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he has strictly no incarnations like those of Vish&#x1e47;u, though V&#x012b;ra-bhadra and the eight Bhairavas and Kha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;o-b&#x0101; &amp;c. {<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 266} are sometimes regarded as forms of him </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is especially worshipped at Benares and has even more names than Vish&#x1e47;u, one thousand and eight being specified in the 69th chapter of the &#x015a;iva-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a and in the 17th chapter of the Anu&#x015b;&#x0101;sana-parvan of the Maha-bh&#x0101;rata, some of the most common being Mah&#x0101;-deva, &#x015a;ambhu, &#x015a;a&#x1e43;kara, &#x012a;&#x015b;a, &#x012a;&#x015b;vara, Mah&#x00ea;&#x015b;vara, Hara </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his sons are Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a and K&#x0101;rttikeya) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 73 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of second Siva (with &#x015a;aivas), a person who has attained a partic. stage of perfection or emancipation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;iva-li&#x1e45;ga</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any god <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a euphemistic N. of a jackal (generally <em>&#x015b;iv&#x0101;</em> f. q.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sacred writings <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in astron.) N. of the sixth month </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a post for cows (to which they are tied or for them to rub against) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; bdellium <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the fragrant bark of Feronia Elephantum <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Marsilia Dentata <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of thorn-apple or = <em>pu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ar&#x012b;ka</em> (the tree) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; quicksilver <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. <em>&#x015b;iva-b&#x012b;ja</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. auspicious constellation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a demon who inflicts diseases <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;ukra</em> m. <em>k&#x0101;la</em> m. <em>vasu</em> m. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the swift antelope <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rum, spirit distilled from molasses <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; buttermilk <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a ruby <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a peg <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; time <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of Medh&#x00e2;tithi <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Idhma-jihva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a prince and various authors (also with <em>d&#x012b;k&#x1e63;ita</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ita</em>, <em>yajvan</em>, <em>s&#x016b;ri</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a fraudulent person <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (du.) the god &#x015a;iva and his wife <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kir">Kir.</a> v, 40 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Praca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;">Praca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;.</a> i, 20 (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> v, 2, 1) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a class of gods in the third Manvantara <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a class of Br&#x0101;hmans who have attained a partic. degree of perfection like that of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. &#x015a;iva's wife (also <em>&#x015b;ivii</em>), <em>&#x015b;iv&#x0101;</em> below </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. welfare, prosperity, bliss (<em>&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>&#x00e9;na</em> or <em>&#x00e9;bhis</em>, 'auspiciously, fortunately, happily, luckily' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;iv&#x0101;ya gamyat&#x0101;m</em>, 'a prosperous journey to you!') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; final emancipation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; water <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rock-salt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sea-salt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of borax <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; iron <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; myrobolan <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Tabernaemontana Coronaria <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sandal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a (= <em>&#x015b;iva-pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> or <em>&#x015b;aiva</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the house in which the P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;avas were to be burnt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a Varsha in Plaksha-dviipa and in Jambu-dviipa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ivaka&#x1e47;&#x1e6d;hamalik&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ka&#x1e47;&#x1e6d;ha-malik&#x0101;</em> f. N. of a Stotra</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ivakara </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kara</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. causing happiness or prosperity, auspicious, propitious <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. (with Jainas) N. of one of the 24 Arhats of the past Utsarpi&#x1e47;&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tva</em> n. childhood, childishness <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pupilage, the period before sixteen <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;n&#x0101;man</em> m. a camel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;i&#x015b;up&#x0101;la </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;p&#x0101;la</em> m. 'child-protector', N. of the king of the Cedis inhabiting a country in central India, probably the same as Bundelkhand ( <em>cedi</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he was son of Dama-ghosha, and is also called Sun&#x012b;tha </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his impiety in opposing the worship of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a is described in the Sabh&#x0101;-parvan of the Mah&#x0101;-bh&#x0101;rata </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; when Yudhi-shthira was about to perform a R&#x0101;jas&#x016b;ya sacrifice, numerous princes attended, and Bhishma proposed that especial honour should be paid to K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a, who was also present, but &#x015a;i&#x015b;u-p&#x0101;la objected, and after denouncing K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a as a contemptible person challenged him to fight, whereupon K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a struck off his head with his discus </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Vish&#x1e47;u-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a identifies this impious monarch with the demons Hira&#x1e47;ya-ka&#x015b;ipu and R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his death forms the subject of M&#x0101;gha's celebrated poem called &#x015a;i&#x015b;up&#x0101;la-vadha) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kath&#x0101;</em> f. N. of a tale </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ni&#x1e63;&#x016b;</em> &#x015a;i&#x015b;p&#x0101;la-vadha) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kath&#x0101;</em> f. N. of a tale </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ni&#x1e63;&#x016b;dana</em> m. destroyer of &#x015a;isu-p&#x0101;la, N. of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-vadha</em> m. 'slaying of &#x015a;isu', N. of a poem by M&#x0101;gha (q.v.) on the above subject </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-vadha-parvan</em> n. N. of a ch. of the Mah&#x0101;-bh&#x0101;rata (&#x012b;, 1418-1627) on the same subject </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;ira&#x015b;-chett&#x1e5b;</em> (cf. Pa&#x00f1;car.) and <em>-han</em> (cf. W.), m. N. of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a</dd>
