           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ek&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;v&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;i&#x1e63;ya</em>, <em>-&#x015b;e&#x1e63;am</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c.), to leave, leave remaining <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> (accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> also 'to distinguish'): Pass. <em>&#x015b;i&#x1e63;y&#x00e1;te</em>, to be left, remain (with <em>na</em>, 'to be lacking') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c.: Caus. (or cl. 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxiv, 11) <em>&#x015b;e&#x1e63;ayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x012b;&#x015b;i&#x1e63;at</em>), to cause or allow to remain, leave, spare <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c.: Desid. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;ik&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;i&#x1e63;yate</em>, <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;e&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;&#x00e1;</em> mfn. left, remaining, escaped, residual (often ifc., e.g. <em>nala-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>', having only the stem left' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>hata-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, 'escaped from slaughter or destruction') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. anything that remains or is left, remains, remnant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. 1</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;at&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;t&#x0101;</em> f</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;atva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tva</em> n. the being left, the being residual <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;abhak&#x1e63;a </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; impf. <em>a&#x015b;eta</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c., 3. pl. <em>a&#x015b;erata</em> [in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> also <em>&#x00e1;&#x015b;eran</em>], p. <em>&#x015b;&#x00e1;y&#x0101;na</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;ye</em>, <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;yire</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. Ved. <em>&#x015b;a&#x015b;ay&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em>, Class. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;y&#x0101;na</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;ayi&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> Subj. <em>&#x015b;&#x00e9;&#x1e63;an</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;ayit&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a>, 2. sg. <em>&#x25cb;t&#x0101;&#x0341;se</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ayi&#x1e63;yate</em>, <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;e&#x1e63;yate</em>, <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x015b;ay&#x00e1;dhyai</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;ayitv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;ayya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a>), to lie, lie down, recline, rest, repose <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to remain unused (as Soma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to lie down to sleep, fall asleep, sleep <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>patye</em>) to lie down to a husband (for sexual intercourse) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>madanena-&#x221a;&#x015b;&#x012b;</em> = 'to be impotent') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a>: Pass. <em>&#x015b;ayyate</em>, Gr. (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x0101;yi</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>, pr.p. once in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;yat</em>): Caus. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;yayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x012b;&#x015b;ayat</em>), to cause to lie down, lay down, put, throw, fix on or in (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to lie down, allow to rest or sleep <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a>: Desid. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;ayi&#x1e63;ate</em>, to wish to rest or sleep <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a>: Intens. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;&#x015b;ayyate</em>, <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;ay&#x012b;ti</em>, <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;eti</em> Gr. [Cf. Gk. [1077, 1] ?, 'to lie' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ?', a bed.']</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;ayana </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ayana</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ayan&#x012b;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ayan&#x012b;ya</em> &amp;c. p. 1055, col. 3</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x012b; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x012b;</em> mfn. (ifc.) lying, resting( <em>jihma-</em>, <em>madhyama-&#x015b;&#x012b;</em>, &amp;c.) </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x012b;r&#x1e63;an </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x012b;r&#x1e63;&#x00e1;n</em> n. (for <em>&#x015b;iras</em> + <em>an</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rare in later language </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Veda has all cases in sg. except nom. acc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also has nom. acc. du. pl. loc. pl </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; later language has only acc. pl. and remaining cases </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. also <em>a-</em>, <em>tri-</em>, <em>sahasra&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) the head (also 'an eminent or illustrious person', cf. cf. RV. vii, 18, 24) cf. RV. &amp;c. &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;&#x012b;l 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x012b;l</em> (rather Nom. fr. <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;la</em> below), cl. 1.P. <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;lati</em> (pf. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;&#x012b;la</em> &amp;c.), to meditate, contemplate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xv, 16 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to serve, worship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to act, do, practise, make <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Caus. (or cl. 10. P. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxv, 26) <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;layati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;&#x012b;lat</em>), to do, make, practise repeatedly or exceedingly, be intent upon or engaged in (acc.), exercise, cultivate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;past">&#x0100;past.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to wear, put on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to visit, frequent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bh&#x0101;m">Bh&#x0101;m.</a> (cf. <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;lita</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to exceed, excel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vop">Vop.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x012b;la </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x012b;&#x0341;la</em> n. (and m. g. <em>ardharc&#x00e2;di</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) habit, custom, usage, natural or acquired way of living or acting, practice, conduct, disposition, tendency, character, nature (often ifc. = 'habituated' or 'accustomed' or 'disposed' or 'addicted to', 'practising' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>gu&#x1e47;a-</em>, <em>d&#x0101;na-</em>, <em>pu&#x1e47;ya-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. good disposition or character, moral conduct, integrity, morality, piety, virtue <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> IW. 208 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;la</em>', moral conduct', is one of the 6 or 10 perfections or P&#x0101;ramit&#x0101;s <em>q.v.</em> and is threefold, viz. <em>sambh&#x0101;ra</em>, <em>ku&#x015b;ala-sa&#x1e43;gr&#x0101;ha</em>, <em>sattv&#x00e2;rtha-kriy&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 106) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a moral precept (with <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> there are 5 fundamental precepts or rules of moral conduct, cf. <em>pa&#x00f1;ca-&#x015b;&#x012b;la</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MWB">MWB.</a> 126 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; form, shape, beauty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a large snake in this sense prob. fr. &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a king <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. below</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; juice, the essence of anything <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> (also pl.) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (also <em>&#x012b;</em>), f. N. of a daughter of T&#x0101;mr&#x0101; and wife of Ka&#x015b;yapa, (regarded as the parent of water-fowl) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;uddha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;uddh&#x00e1;</em> mfn. cleansed, cleared, clean, pure, clear, free from (with instr.), bright, white <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cleared, acquitted, free from error, faultless, blameless, right, correct, accurate, exact, according to rule <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; upright ( comp.) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; complete, entire <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; N. of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-k&#x0101;yika</em> m. (with <em>deva</em>) a god belonging to the class who dwell in that region <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-devaputra</em> m. a Deva-putra belonging to the above class <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;">K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;uddhi </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;ddhi</em> f. cleansing, purification, purity (lit. and fig.), holiness, freedom from defilement, purificatory rite (esp. a partic. &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha performed at the cost of a person who needs purification) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; setting free or securing (from any danger), rendering secure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;m">K&#x0101;m.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; justification, exculpation, innocence (established by ordeal or trial), acquittal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; quittance, clearing off or paying off, discharge (of a debt &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; retaliation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; verification, correction, making true, correctness, accuracy, genuineness, truth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;lat&#x012b;m">M&#x0101;lat&#x012b;m.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; clearness, certainty, accurate knowledge regarding (gen. or comp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;uddhi&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>', to ascertain for certain' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;"&#x1e63;-&#x221a;labh</em>', to receive certain intelligence') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vet">Vet.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1082-3"></a>[Page 1082, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in arithm.) leaving no remainder (<em>&#x015b;uddhim-&#x221a;i</em>', to leave no remainder'), B&#x012b;jag </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; subtraction of a quantity or a quantity to be subtracted, Lil </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Durg&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of one of the &#x015a;aktis of Vish&#x1e47;u <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of D&#x0101;ksh&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;&#x012b; as worshipped at Kap&#x0101;la-mocana <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;una 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;un&#x00e1;</em> m. (prob. fr. &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;&#x016b;</em> or <em>&#x015b;vi</em>, and connected with <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;ra</em>, <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;&#x1e63;a</em> &amp;c.) 'the Auspicious one', N. of V&#x0101;yu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; n. growth, success, prosperity, welfare <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x00e1;m</em>), ind. happily, auspiciously, for growth or prosperity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;n&#x0101;-s&#x012b;&#x0341;ra</em> m. du. N. of two rural deities favourable to the growth of grain (prob. personifications of 'share' and 'plough' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but identified by Y&#x0101;ska with V&#x0101;yu and &#x0100;ditya, by others with Indra and V&#x0101;yu or Indra and S&#x016b;rya) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sg. (also written <em>sun&#x25cb;</em>) N. of Indra (cf. <em>vasu&#x1e43;dhar&#x0101;-&#x015b;un&#x25cb;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) a partic. class of gods (also written <em>sun&#x25cb;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;ar&#x00e2;sana</em> n. 'Indra's bow', a rainbow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcar">Hcar.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;rin</em> mfn. (applied to Indra) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;r&#x012b;&#x0341;ya</em> or <em>&#x25cb;ry&#x00e1;</em> mfn. belonging or relating to &#x015a;un&#x0101;-sira <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-2, 32) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. or (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of partic. oblations <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;una&#x1e25;puccha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;puccha</em> m. 'dogtailed', N. of one of the three sons of &#x1e5a;ic&#x012b;ka (or accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> the eldest of the three sons of Ajigarta) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the author of a law-book (<em>-sm&#x1e5b;ti</em> f. his wk.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;una&#x1e25;&#x015b;epa </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;na&#x1e25;-&#x015b;&#x00e9;pa</em> m. 'dog-tailed', N. of a Vedic &#x1e5a;ishi (having the patr. &#x0100;j&#x012b;garti, as son of Ajigarta or Aj&#x012b;garta, and regarded as the author of the hymns i, 24-30, ix, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> vii, 13-18, king Hari&#x015b;candra, whose priest was Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;-mitra, being childless, made a vow that on obtaining a son he would sacrifice him to the god Varu&#x1e47;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a son was then born to him named Rohita, but Hari&#x015b;candra put off on various pretexts the fulfilment of his vow, and when he at length consented to perform it, his son refused to be sacrificed, and retiring to the forest passed six years there until he met a poor Br&#x0101;hman &#x1e5a;ishi named Ajigarta, who had three sons, the second of whom, &#x015a;una-&#x015b;epa, was purchased by Rohita for a hundred cows to serve as a substitute for himself <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1083-1"></a>[Page 1083, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Varu&#x1e47;a having accepted him as a ransom, he was about to be sacrificed, Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;-mitra being Hot&#x1e5b;i priest, when he saved himself by reciting verses in praise of various deities, and was received into the family of Vi&#x015b;m&#x0101;-mitra as one of his sons under the name of Deva-r&#x0101;ta, q.v.: the legend is different in the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, which makes Ambar&#x012b;sha, king of Ayodhya, perform a sacrifice, the victim of which is stolen by Indra </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this king is described as wandering over the earth in search of either the real victim or a substitute until he meets with a Br&#x0101;hman named &#x1e5a;icika, from whom he purchases his middle son, &#x015a;unah-&#x015b;epa, who is about to be sacrificed, when Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;-mitra saves him by teaching him a prayer to Agni and two hymns to Indra and Vish&#x1e47;u </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> i, 61, 62) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (cf. IW. 25-27) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. the genital organ of a dog <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;una&#x1e25;&#x015b;epa&#x015b;epha </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a &#x1e5a;ishi <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of an &#x0100;&#x1e45;girasa and disciple of Pathya <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a king <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Ruru <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of the slayer of Puram-jaya and father of Pradyota <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x015b;aunaka</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. the family or race of &#x015a;unaka <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> (cf. <em>&#x015b;aunaka</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a bitch <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ubh 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ubh</em> (or 1. <em>&#x015b;umbh</em>), cl. 1. &#x0100;. or 6. P. (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xviii, 11 ; xxviii, 33) <em>&#x015b;&#x00f3;bhate</em>, <em>&#x015b;umbh&#x00e1;ti</em> or <em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;mbhati</em> (ep. also <em>&#x015b;obhati</em>, and Ved. <em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;mbhate</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. sg. <em>&#x015b;&#x00f3;bhe</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;obha</em>, <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;ubhe</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;umbha</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor., <em>a&#x015b;ubhat</em>, <em>a&#x015b;obhi&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>a&#x015b;umbh&#x012b;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;mbh&#x0101;na</em>, <em>&#x015b;ubh&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;obhit&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x015b;umbhit&#x0101;</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;obhi&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;umbhi&#x1e63;yati</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x015b;ubh&#x00e9;</em>, <em>&#x015b;obh&#x0101;se</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;obhitum</em> Gr.), to beautify, embellish, adorn, beautify one's self. (&#x0100;.) look beautiful or handsome, shine, be bright or splendid </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>iva</em> or <em>yath&#x0101;</em>, 'to shine or look like' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>na</em>', to look bad, have a bad appearance, appear to disadvantage') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to prepare, make fit or ready, (&#x0100;.) prepare one's self. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;mbhate</em> accord. to some) to flash or flit i.e. glide rapidly past or along <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (cf. <em>&#x015b;ubh&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em>, <em>&#x015b;umbh&#x00e1;m&#x0101;na</em>, and <em>pra-&#x221a;&#x015b;umbh</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;umbhati</em>) wrongly for <em>&#x015b;undhati</em> (to be connected with &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;udh</em>, to purify) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vi, 155, 3 ; xii, 2, 40 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;umbhati</em>) to harm, injure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xi, 42 (in this sense rather to be regarded as a second &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;umbh</em>, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;2">&#x221a;2.</a> <em>&#x015b;umbh</em>, <em>ni-&#x015b;umbh</em>): Pass. aor. <em>a&#x015b;obhi-tar&#x0101;m</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Inscr">Inscr.</a>: Caus. <em>&#x015b;bhayati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x016b;&#x015b;ubhat</em> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1083-2"></a>[Page 1083, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>&#x015b;obhita</em>), to cause to shine beautify, ornament, decorate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;ubh&#x00e1;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>) to ornament, decorate, (&#x0100;.) decorate one's self. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (only pr. p. <em>&#x015b;ubh&#x00e1;yat</em>), to fly rapidly along <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>: Desid. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;obhi&#x1e63;ate</em> (accord. to Gr. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em>, and <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;ubhi&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>), to wish to prepare or make ready <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> viii, 10: Intens. <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;ubhyate</em> (Gr. also <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;obdhi</em>), to shine brightly or in tensely, be very splendid or beautiful <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;ubh 2</dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; eager to obey, obedient, attentive, serving, attending on (gen. or comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;u&#x015b;r&#x016b;&#x1e63;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;r&#x016b;&#x1e0d;&#x1e63;ya</em> mfn. to be heard or obeyed or served <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;u&#x1e63; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;u&#x1e63;</em> (prob. for orig. <em>su&#x1e63;</em>, <em>sus</em>), cl. 4.P. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxvi, 74) <em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;&#x1e63;yati</em> (m. c. also <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;o&#x1e63;a</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;u&#x1e63;at</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;&#x0101;</em>, <em>&#x015b;ok&#x1e63;yati</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;um</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>-&#x015b;&#x00fa;&#x1e63;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a>), to dry, become dry or withered, fade, languish, decay <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c.: Caus. <em>&#x015b;o&#x1e63;ayati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;&#x016b;&#x015b;u&#x1e63;at</em>), to make dry, dry up, wither, parch <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to afflict, injure, hurt, extinguish, destroy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>: Desid. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;uk&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;u&#x1e63;yate</em>, <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;o&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> [Cf. Gk. ? for ? ; [1084, 3] Lat. <em>siccus</em> ; Slav. [suchati] ; Lith. <em>sus&#x00fa;</em>, <em>sausi&#x00fa;</em>, <em>sa&#x00fa;sas</em> &amp;c.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;u&#x1e63; 2</dt>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x016b;nya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x016b;ny&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>) n. empty, void (with <em>v&#x0101;jin</em> = 'a riderless horse' </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; empty, i.e. vacant (as a look or stare), absent, absentminded, having no certain object or aim, distracted <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; empty i.e. possessing nothing, wholly destitute <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; wholly alone or solitary, having no friends or companions <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; vain, idle, unreal, nonsensical <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; void of results, ineffectual (<em>a-&#x015b;&#x016b;nya&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, 'to effect', accomplish') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ratn&#x00e2;v">Ratn&#x00e2;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; free from sensitiveness or sensation (said of the skin), insensible <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhpr">Bhpr.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 20, 12, the &#x015a;&#x016b;dra is said to have been born from the feet of Purusha, q.v </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>kevala-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, a pure &#x015a;&#x016b;dra) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (cf. IW. 212 &amp;c.) </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;&#x016b;l</em> (rather Nom. fr. next), cl. 1. P. <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;lati</em>, to hurt, cause pain (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xv, 19), (only occurring in &#x0100;. <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;late</em> and cl. 4.            <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> also <em>sa&#x1e43;gho&#x1e63;e</em>, or <em>sa&#x1e43;gh&#x0101;te</em>, 'to sound' or 'to collect')</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;&#x016b;la </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; any sharp instrument or pointed dart, lance, pike, spear (esp. the trident of &#x015a;iva) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a stake for impaling criminals (<em>&#x015b;&#x016b;lam &#x0101;-&#x221a;ruh</em>, 'to be fixed on a stake, suffer impalement' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Caus. of <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;ruh</em>, 'to fix on a stake, have any one <em>acc.</em> impaled', cf. <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;l&#x00e2;dhiropita</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any sharp or acute pain (esp. that of colic or gout) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;e&#x1e63;e r&#x0101;trau</em>, 'during the rest of the night' </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>iti &#x015b;e&#x1e63;a&#x1e25;</em>, 'so it was left to be supplied', a phrase commonly used by <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> in supplying any words necessary to elucidate the text) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; that which is saved or spared or allowed to escape (nom. with &#x221a;<em>as</em>, or &#x221a;<em>bh&#x016b;</em>, 'to be spared' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;e&#x1e63;a&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>', to spare', 'allow to escape' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;e&#x1e63;am av&#x00e2;p</em> 'to escape') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; remaining (used as an adj. at the end of adj. comp. [f. <em>&#x0101;</em>], cf. <em>kath&#x0101;-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>, <em>k&#x1e5b;tya-&#x015b;&#x25cb;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; remaining out of or from, left from (with abl. or loc., e.g. <em>pray&#x0101;tebhyo ye &#x015b;e&#x1e63;&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>, 'the persons left out of those who had departed' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but mostly ifc. after a pp. in comp., e.g. <em>bhukta-&#x015b;e&#x1e63;a</em>, 'remaining from a meal', 'remnant of food' </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; end, issue, conclusion, finish, result <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> 77, 15 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; death, destruction <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a celebrated mythological thousand-headed serpent regarded as the emblem of eternity (whence he is also called An-anta', the infinite' ; in the Vish&#x1e47;u-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a he and the serpents V&#x0101;suki and Takshaka are described as sons of Kadru, but in one place &#x015a;esha alone is called king of the N&#x0101;gas or snakes inhabiting P&#x0101;t&#x0101;la, while elsewhere V&#x0101;suki also is described as king of the Nagas and Takshaka of the serpents ; the thousand headed &#x015a;esha is sometimes represented as forming the couch and canopy of Vish&#x1e47;u whilst sleeping during the intervals of creation, sometimes as supporting the seven P&#x0101;t&#x0101;las with the seven regions above them and therefore the entire world <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1089-1"></a>[Page 1089, Column 1]</font>
 ; he is said to have taught astronomy to Garga ; according to some legends he became incarnate in Bala-r&#x0101;ma, q.v.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> &amp;c.            <dt>&#x015b;ail&#x016b;&#x1e63;a </dt>

           <dt>&#x015b;aile&#x015b;caya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;aile&#x015b;caya</em> (?),         <br>          m. (prob. w&#x1e5b;. for. <em>&#x015b;aile-&#x015b;aya</em>) N. of a man (pl. his family) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pravar">Pravar.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;aiva 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;aiva</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>&#x015b;iva</em>) relating or belonging or sacred to the god &#x015a;iva, coming or derived from &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. patr. fr. <em>&#x015b;iva</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-1, 112 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'a worshipper or follower of &#x015a;iva', N. of one of the three great divisions of modern Hind&#x016b;ism (the other two being the Vaish&#x1e47;avas and &#x015a;&#x0101;ktas, qq. vv </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the &#x015a;aivas identify &#x015a;iva-rather than Brahm&#x0101; and Vish&#x1e47;u-with the Supreme Being and are exclusively devoted to his worship, regarding him as the source and essence of the universe as well as its disintegrator and destroyer </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the temples dedicated to him in his reproducing and vivifying character [as denoted by the Li&#x1e45;ga, q.v.] are scattered all over India </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the various sects of &#x015a;aivas are described in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 86 &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a particular religious rite in honour of Durg&#x0101; (consisting of devout meditation and prostration of the body) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the thorn-apple <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of plant (= <em>vasuka</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Jainas), N. of the fifth black V&#x0101;sudeva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. N. of the goddess M&#x0101;nas&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. auspiciousness, welfare, prosperity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a &#x015a;&#x0101;stra and of a Tantra and of a Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a ( below)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;aivakalpadruma </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; an ascetic (who has given up worldly pursuits) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> iv, 30 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. pride, manliness <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> (perhaps w&#x1e5b;. for <em>&#x015b;au&#x1e6d;&#x012b;rya</em>)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; esp. of the celebrated grammarian, author of the Rig-veda Pr&#x0101;ti&#x015b;&#x0101;khya, the B&#x1e5b;ihad-devat&#x0101;, and various other wks </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is described as the teacher of K&#x0101;ty&#x0101;yana and especially of &#x0100;sval&#x0101;yana </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is said to have united the B&#x0101;shkala and &#x015a;&#x0101;kala &#x015a;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;s, and is sometimes identified with the Vedic &#x1e5a;ishi G&#x1e5b;itsa-mada </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but according to the Vish&#x1e47;u-Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a, &#x015a;&#x0101;kh&#x0101;s was a son of G&#x1e5b;itsamada, and originated the system of four castes </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is quoted in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#APr&#x0101;t">APr&#x0101;t.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VPr&#x0101;t">VPr&#x0101;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the various legends about him are very confused) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;raddh&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;raddh&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> f. faith, trust, confidence, trustfulness, faithfulness, belief in (loc. or comp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;raddhay&#x0101;-&#x221a;gam</em>, 'to believe in', with gen. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Divy&#x00e2;v">Divy&#x00e2;v.</a>), trust, confidence, loyalty (Faith or Faithfulnesses is often personified and in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 151 invoked as a deity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> she is the daughter of Praj&#x0101;-pati, and in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> of the Sun </dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;rath </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;rath</em> or <em>&#x015b;ranth</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;lath</em>), cl. 9. P. (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxi, 39) <em>&#x015b;rathn&#x0101;ti</em> (Ved. also <em>&#x015b;rathn&#x012b;te</em> and <em>&#x015b;&#x1e5b;nthati</em>, and accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> also <em>&#x015b;rathati</em>, <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;thayati</em>, <em>&#x015b;ranthati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>&#x015b;a&#x015b;r&#x0101;tha</em> or <em>&#x015b;a&#x015b;rantha</em> Gr </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; 3. pl. <em>&#x015b;rethu&#x1e25;</em> or <em>&#x015b;a&#x015b;ranthu&#x1e25;</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;ranth&#x012b;t</em>, <em>&#x25cb;thi&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;ranthi&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;rathitv&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x015b;ranthitv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;rathya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a>), to be loosened or untied or unbent, become loose or slack, yield, give way <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-1, 89 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make slack, disable, disarm <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 171, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;.) to loosen one's own (bonds &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; v. l. for <em>grath</em>, <em>granth</em>: Caus. <em>&#x015b;rath&#x00e1;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (in Sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;p. also <em>&#x015b;rath&#x0101;yati</em> and accord. to Gr. also <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;thayati</em> and <em>&#x015b;ranthayati</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#below]">below].</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;rathat</em> [3. sg. Subj. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;rathat</em> and 3. pl.            <dd>&#x2022; to remit, Pardon (sin) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;thayati</em>), to strive eagerly, endeavour, use exertion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxii, 13 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to delight, gladden <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to hurt, kill <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;rama&#x1e47;&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x012b;</em>)n. making effort or exertion, toiling, labouring, (esp.) following a toilsome or menial business <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; base, vile, bad <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. one who performs acts of mortification or austerity, an ascetic, monk, devotee, religious mendicant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a Buddhist monk or mendicant (also applied to Buddha himself, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> MWB. 23 &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a serpent-demon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a handsome woman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;rap&#x0101;yya</em> m. (fr. id.) a sacrificial animal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;rapita </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;rapita</em> mfn. (fr. id.) caused to be cooked or boiled <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 27 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. rice-gruel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. boiled meat &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;r&#x0101;&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> mfn. cooked, boiled <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 27 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; moist, wet <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. rice gruel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. boiled meat &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;r&#x0101;ta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;t&#x00e1;</em> mfn. (cf. <em>&#x015b;&#x1e5b;t&#x00e1;</em>) cooked, boiled, roasted <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> [Cf. Gk. ? in ?.] [1097, 3]</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;r&#x0101;pin </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;pin</em> mfn. (fr Caus.), cooking, boiling <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty">K&#x0101;ty.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;r&#x0101;ddha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;ddha</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>&#x015b;rad-dh&#x0101;</em>) faithful, true, loyal, believing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#HPari&#x015b;">HPari&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#SaddhP">SaddhP.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 5-2, 101) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating to a &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha ceremony <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. a ceremony in honour and for the benefit of dead relatives observed with great strictness at various fixed periods and on occasions of rejoicing as well as mourning by the surviving relatives (these ceremonies are performed by the daily offering of water and on stated occasions by the offering of Pi&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;as or balls of rice and meal [see <em>pi&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em>] to three paternal and three maternal forefathers, i.e. to father, grandfather, and great grandfather </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it should be borne in mind that a &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha is not a funeral ceremouy [<em>anty&#x00ea;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em>] but a supplement to such a ceremony </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is an act of reverential homage to a deceased person performed by relatives, and is moreover supposed to supply the dead with strengthening nutriment after the performance of the previous funeral ceremonies has endowed them with ethereal bodies </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; indeed until those <em>anty&#x00ea;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em>, or 'funeral rites' have been performed, and until the succeeding first &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha has been celebrated the deceased relative is a <em>pr&#x00ea;ta</em> or restless, wandering ghost, and has no real body [only a <em>li&#x1e45;ga-&#x015b;ar&#x012b;ra</em>, q.v.] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is not until the first &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha has taken place that he attains a position among the Pit&#x1e5b;is or Divine Fathers in their blissful abode called Pit&#x1e5b;i-loka, and the &#x015a;r&#x1e6d;&#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha is most desirable and efficacious when performed by a son </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for a full description of the &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha ceremonies, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 276, 304 &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; gifts or offerings at a &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;r&#x0101;ddhakara </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kara</em> and m. one who performs a &#x015a;r&#x0101;ddha or offers an oblation to the Pit&#x1e5b;is <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vasta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vasta</em> m. (prob. connected with &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;ru</em>) N. of a king (son of &#x015a;r&#x0101;va and grandson of Yuvan&#x0101;&#x015b;va) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. N. of a city situated north of the Ganges and founded by king &#x015a;r&#x0101;vasta (it was the ancient capital of Kosala and said to have been the place where the wealthy merchant An&#x0101;tha-pi&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ika built the Buddha a residence in the Jeta-vana monastery which became his favourite retreat during the rainy seasons: other authorities derive the name from a &#x1e5a;ishi called S&#x0101;vattha, who is said to have resided there </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it has been identified by General Cunningham with a place now called S&#x0101;hetM&#x0101;het, about 58 miles north of Ayodhy&#x0101; in Oudh) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MWB">MWB.</a> 48 ; 407 &amp;c.)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; [azrAyiSTa] Gr. [Ved. forms belonging either to the pf. or aor. type are also <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;ret</em>, <em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;rema</em>, <em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;rayu&#x1e25;</em>, <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;r&#x012b;t&#x00e1;</em>] </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;rayi&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;rayitv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c., <em>-&#x015b;r&#x00ed;tya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c.), P. to cause to lean or rest on, lay on or in, fix on, fasten to, direct or turn towards, (esp.) spread or diffuse (light or radiance or beauty) over (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;. or Pass., rarely P.) to lean on, rest on, recline against (acc.), cling to (loc.), be supported or fixed or depend on, abide in or on (acc., loc. or adv.)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;vG&#x1e5b;">&#x0100;&#x015b;vG&#x1e5b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;. P.) to go to, approach, resort or have recourse to (for help or refuge), tend towards (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;.) to go into, enter, fall to the lot or take possession of (acc. or loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;. P.) to attain, undergo, get into any state or condition (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to show, betray (heroism) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to honour, worship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a>: Pass.            <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;yayati</em> (aor. <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;rayat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;riyat</em>, above), Gr.: Desid. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;rayi&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> or <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;r&#x012b;&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;r&#x012b;yate</em>, <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;ray&#x012b;ti</em>, <em>&#x015b;e&#x015b;reti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> [Cf.            <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;rita </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; one who has gone or resorted to (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; having attained or fallen or got into any condition (acc. or comp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>ka&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a-&#x015b;r&#x25cb;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; gone to, approached, had recourse to, sought, occupied (as a place) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; taken, chosen <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x1e63;ama</em> mfn. one who has had recourse to patience, composed, tranquil <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;atr">&#x015a;atr.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;sattva</em> mfn. one who has taken courage or resolution <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;riti</em> f. approach, recourse, entering ( <em>ucchriti</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em>) = <em>&#x015b;&#x1e5b;tyai</em>, <em>&#x015b;raya&#x1e47;&#x00e2;rtham</em> (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 14, 6</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;rimanya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ri-manya</em> n. (fr. 2. <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> + <em>manya</em>, connected with <em>&#x015b;riyam-many&#x0101;</em> below <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-3, 68, Vartt. 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;riyammanya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;riyam-manya</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. fancying one's self &#x015a;r&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-3, 68 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; conceited, proud, arrogant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;riyadhyai </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;riyadhyai</em> <em>&#x015b;riy&#x00e1;se</em>, <em>&#x015b;riy&#x0101;</em> &amp;c. p. 1100, col. 2</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;riyaputra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;riya-putra</em> w&#x1e5b;. for <em>priya-p&#x25cb;</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;riv </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;riv</em> &#x221a;<em>sriv</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ri&#x1e63; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ri&#x1e63;</em> (cf. &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;li&#x1e63;</em>), cl. 1. P. <em>&#x015b;re&#x1e63;ati</em>, to burn <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xvii, 51</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;ri&#x1e63; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ri&#x1e63;</em> (prob. a collateral form of &#x221a;2. <em>&#x015b;li&#x1e63;</em>), in <em>&#x015b;re&#x1e63;&#x0101;ma</em> (accord to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;y">S&#x0101;y.</a>) = <em>&#x015b;le&#x1e63;ayema</em>, 'may we connect or compose' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 43, 1, and <em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;li&#x1e63;at</em> = <em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;li&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a&#x1e43; m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;t</em>, 'let it not be left on the ground' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> i, 162, 11 (cf. <em>abhi-&#x015b;r&#x00ed;&#x1e63;</em>, <em>do&#x1e63;a&#x1e47;i&#x015b;r&#x00ed;&#x1e63;</em>, <em>h&#x1e5b;daya-&#x015b;r&#x00ed;&#x1e63;</em>, <em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;r&#x00e9;&#x1e63;a</em>, <em>sa&#x1e43;-&#x015b;re&#x1e63;a&#x1e47;&#x00ed;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;r&#x012b; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;</em>), cl. 9. P. &#x0100;. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxxi, 3) <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;&#x1e47;&#x00e1;ti</em>, <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;&#x1e47;&#x012b;t&#x00e9;</em> (Gr. also pf. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;r&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;r&#x012b;ye</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;rai&#x1e63;&#x012b;t</em>, <em>a&#x015b;re&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;rayu&#x1e25;</em> 2. <em>abhi-&#x221a;&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em>), to mix, mingle, cook (cf. <em>abhi-</em> and <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (= &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;ri</em>), to burn, flame, diffuse light <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 68, 1</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;r&#x012b; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> mfn. (ifc.) mixing, mingling, mixed with </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; f. mixing, cooking</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;r&#x012b;ta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;t&#x00e1;</em> mfn. mixed, mixed with (instr.), cooked <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;r&#x012b; 3</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> f. (prob. to be connected with &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;ri</em> and also with &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> in the sense of 'diffusing light or radiance' <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1098-3"></a>[Page 1098, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; nom. <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;&#x0341;s</em> accord. to some also <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em>) light, lustre, radiance, splendour, glory, beauty, grace, loveliness (<em>&#x015b;riy&#x00e9;</em> and <em>&#x015b;riya&#x00ed;</em>, 'for splendour or beauty', 'beauteously', gloriously', cf. <em>&#x015b;riy&#x00e1;se</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. <em>&#x015b;riyau</em>, 'beauty and prosperity' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;riya &#x0101;tmaj&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>, 'sons of beauty', i.e. horses [cf. <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;-putra</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;riya&#x1e25; putr&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>', goats with auspicious marks') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; prosperity, welfare, good fortune, success, auspiciousness, wealth, treasure, riches (<em>&#x015b;riy&#x0101;</em>, 'accord&#x1e6d;according to fortune or wealth'), high rank, power, might, majesty, royal dignity (or 'Royal dignity' personified </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;riyo bh&#x0101;ja&#x1e25;</em>, 'possessors of dignity', 'people of high rank') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; symbol or insignia of royalty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vikr">Vikr.</a> iv, 13 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Lakshm&#x012b; (as goddess of prosperity or beauty and wife of Vish&#x1e47;u, produced at the churning of the ocean, also as daughter of Bh&#x1e5b;igu and as mother of Darpa) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Sarasvat&#x012b; ( <em>-pa&#x00f1;cam&#x012b;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a daughter of king Su-&#x015b;arman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of various metres <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Col">Col.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (the following only in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> 'a lotus-flower </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; intellect, understanding </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; speech </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cloves </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pinus Longifolia </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Aegle Marmelos </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of drug, = <em>v&#x1e5b;ddhi</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Buddhist goddess and of the mother of the 17th Arhat') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of the fifth musical R&#x0101;ga ( <em>r&#x0101;ga</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sa&#x1e43;g&#x012b;t">Sa&#x1e43;g&#x012b;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mfn. diffusing light or radiance, splendid, radiant, beautifying, adorning (ifc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>agni-</em>, <em>adhvara-</em>, <em>k&#x1e63;atra-</em>, <em>ga&#x1e47;a-</em>, <em>jana-&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 41, 8. [The word <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em> is frequently used as an honorific prefix (= 'sacred', 'holy') to the names of deities (e.g. &#x015a;ri-Durg&#x0101;, &#x015a;r&#x012b;-R&#x0101;ma), and may be repeated two, three, or even four times to express excessive veneration. (e.g. &#x015a;r&#x012b;-&#x015b;r&#x012b;-Durg&#x0101; &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is also used as a respectful title (like 'Reverend') to the names of eminent persons as well as of celebrated works and sacred objects (e. g. &#x015a;r&#x012b;-Jayadeva. &#x015a;r&#x012b;Bh&#x0101;gavata), and is often placed at the beginning or back of letters, manuscripts, important documents &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also before the words <em>cara&#x1e47;a</em> and <em>p&#x0101;da</em> 'feet', and even the end of personal names.]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. mark or curl of hair on the breast of Vish&#x1e47;u or K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a (and of other divine beings </dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;ry&#x0101;hva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x0101;hva</em> n. 'having the name of &#x015a;r&#x012b;', a lotus-flower (the goddess &#x015a;r&#x012b; or Lakshm&#x012b; having appeared with a lotus, the type of beauty, in her hand and being connected with it in many of her names, cf. <em>padm&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;r&#x012b;kaj&#x0101;ka </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;kaj&#x0101;ka</em> (?), n. a building of a partic. form <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; aor. Ved. <em>&#x00e1;&#x015b;ravam</em>, <em>&#x00e1;&#x015b;rot</em>, 2. sg. <em>&#x015b;r&#x00f3;&#x1e63;i</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Subj. <em>&#x015b;r&#x00e1;vat</em>, <em>&#x25cb;vatha&#x1e25;</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>&#x015b;rot&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>&#x015b;rotum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>&#x015b;rutv&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;r&#x00fa;tya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vam</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> &amp;c.), to hear, listen or attend to anything (acc.), give ear to any one (acc. or gen.), hear or learn anything about (acc.) or from (abl., gen., instr., <em>mukh&#x0101;t</em> or <em>&#x015b;ak&#x0101;&#x015b;&#x0101;t</em>), or that anything is (two acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to hear (from a teacher), study, learn <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be attentive, be obedient, obey <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c.: Pass. <em>&#x015b;r&#x016b;y&#x00e1;te</em> (ep. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <em>&#x015b;&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;ve</em> &amp;c. {cf. above} with pass. meaning </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;r&#x0101;vi</em>, <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vi</em>), to be heard or perceived or learnt about (acc.) or from (gen., abl. or <em>mukh&#x0101;t</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in later language often 3. sg. <em>&#x015b;r&#x016b;yate</em> impers. 'it is heard', 'one hears or learns or reads in a book', = 'it is said', 'it is written in (with loc.)' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. <em>&#x015b;r&#x016b;yat&#x0101;m</em>, 'let it be heard' = 'listen!') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be celebrated or renowned, be known as, pass for, be called (nom.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1101-1"></a>[Page 1101, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be heard or learnt (from a teacher) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be taught or stated (in a book) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be heard i.e. pronounced or employed (as a sound or word) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TPr&#x0101;t">TPr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>: Caus. <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;v&#x00e1;yati</em> (ep. also <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> also <em>&#x015b;rav&#x00e1;yati</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>a&#x015b;u&#x015b;ravi</em>, <em>&#x25cb;vu&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>a&#x015b;u&#x015b;ruvat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>a&#x015b;i&#x015b;ravat</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vyate</em>, below), to cause to be heard or learnt, announce, proclaim, declare <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to hear, inform, instruct, communicate, relate, tell (with acc. of thing, and acc., gen., or dat. of pers., or with instr. in sense of 'through') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Pass. of Caus. <em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;vyate</em>, to be informed of (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Desid. <em>&#x015b;&#x00fa;&#x015b;r&#x016b;&#x1e63;ate</em> (cf.            <dd>&#x2022; ep. or m. c. also <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;r&#x016b;&#x1e63;yate</em>), to wish or like to hear (acc.), desire to attend or listen to (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to attend upon, serve, obey (acc., rarely gen.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Caus. of Desid. <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;r&#x016b;&#x1e63;ayati</em>, to wait upon, be at the service of (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kull">Kull.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ii, 243: Desid. of Caus. <em>&#x015b;i&#x015b;r&#x0101;vayi&#x1e63;ati</em> or <em>&#x015b;u&#x015b;r&#x0101;vayi&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;r&#x016b;yate</em>, <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;raviiti</em>, <em>&#x015b;o&#x015b;roti</em>, Gr.            <dd><em>&#x015b;rut&#x00e1;</em> mfn. heard, listened to, heard about or of, taught, mentioned, orally transmitted or communicated from age to age <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; known, famous, celebrated <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. anything heard, that which has been heard (esp. from the beginning), knowledge as heard by holy men and transmitted from generation to generation, oral tradition or revelation, sacred knowledge (in the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> personified as a child of Dharma and Medh&#x0101;), the Veda <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the act of hearing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up">Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; learning or teaching, instruction (<em>&#x015b;ruta&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, 'to learn') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;past">&#x0100;past.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; memory, remembrance <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> i, 1, 2</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ruti&#x1e43; vaco'nug&#x0101;&#x1e43;-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, 'to listen to a speech') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the ear, organ or power of hearing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the diagonal of a tetragon or hypothenuse of a triangle <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gol">Gol.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p1101-3"></a>[Page 1101, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; that which is heard or perceived with the ear, sound, noise &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an aggregate of sounds (whether forming a word or any part of a word) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TPr&#x0101;t">TPr&#x0101;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rumour, report, news, intelligence, hearsay (<em>&#x015b;rutau-&#x221a;sth&#x0101;</em>, 'to be known by hearsay') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a saying, saw, word <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; that which has been heard or communicated from the beginning, sacred knowledge orally transmitted by the Br&#x0101;hmans from generation to generation, the Veda (i.e. sacred eternal sounds or words as eternally heard by certain holy sages called &#x1e5a;ishis, and so differing from <em>sm&#x1e5b;&#x0301;ti</em> or what is only remembered and handed down in writing by human authors, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ii, 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is properly only applied to the Mantra and Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;a portion of the Vedas, although afterwards extended to the Upanishads and other Vedic works including the Dar&#x015b;anas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>iti &#x015b;rute&#x1e25;</em>, 'because it is so taught in the Veda, according to a <em>&#x015b;ruti</em> or Vedic text' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. 'sacred texts, the Vedas', also 'rites prescribed by the Vedas') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 144 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in music) a particular division of the octave, a quarter tone or interval (twenty-two of these are enumerated, four constituting a major tone, three a minor, and two a semitone </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are said to be personified as nymphs) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;car">Pa&#x00f1;car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a name, title <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d">K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d.</a> ii, 331 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; learning, scholarship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> (prob. w&#x1e5b;. for <em>&#x015b;ruta</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>buddhi</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a daughter of Atri and wife of Kardama <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x015b;reyas </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x00e9;yas</em> mfn. (either compar. of <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;</em>, or rather accord. to native authorities of <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;-mat</em> or <em>pra&#x015b;asya</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gk">Gk.</a> ?) more splendid or beautiful, [1102, 2] more excellent or distinguished, superior, preferable, better, better than (with abl. or with <em>na</em>, below) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; most excellent, best <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 1256 </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x015b;r&#x00f3;&#x1e63;am&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> mfn. (cf. <em>&#x015b;ru&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em>) willing, obedient, confident <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;rauta </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;rauta</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em> or <em>&#x0101;</em>)n. relating to the ear or hearing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be heard, audible, expressed in words or in plain language (as a simile, opp. to <em>&#x0101;rtha</em>, 'implied') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kpr">Kpr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating to sacred tradition, prescribed by or founded on or conformable to the Veda (with <em>janman</em> n. 'the second birth of a Br&#x0101;hman produced by knowledge of the Veda') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sacrificial <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. relationship resulting from (common study of) the Veda <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a fault (incurred in repeating the Veda) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any observance ordained by the Veda (e.g. preservation of the sacred fire) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the three sacred fires collectively <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of various S&#x0101;mans <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;rshBr">&#x0100;rshBr.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; adhering to one's self, i.e. not affecting others, merely personal (as an art or science) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;lav">M&#x0101;lav.</a> i, 15 (v. l. <em>&#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em>) </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x015b;loka </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;l&#x00f3;ka</em> m. (prob. connected with &#x221a;1. <em>&#x015b;ru</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> i, 2, 33 gives a fanciful derivation fr. <em>&#x015b;oka</em>, 'sorrow', the first <em>&#x015b;loka</em> having been composed by V&#x0101;lm&#x012b;ki grieved at seeing a bird killed) sound, noise (as of the wheels of a carriage or the grinding of stones &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a call or voice (of the gods) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fame renown, glory, praise, hymn of praise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a proverb, maxim <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a stanza, (esp.) a partic. kind of common epic metre (also called Anu-sh&#x1e6d;ubh, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; consisting of 4 P&#x0101;das or quarter verses of 8 syllables each, or 2 lines of 16 syllables each, each line allowing great liberty except in the 5th, 13th, 14th and 15th syllables which should be unchangeable as in the following scheme, 8. 1.. 8-8., the dots denoting either long or short </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but the 6th and 7th syllables should be long </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or if the 6th is short the 7th should be short also) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#KaushUp">KaushUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a S&#x0101;man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;rshBr">&#x0100;rshBr.</a></dd>
